entry.title: extreme cold warning in effect
entry.summary:
Description: Extremely cold wind chill values near minus 50 will continue tonight and into the weekend. ### Extreme cold puts everyone at risk. Risks are greater for young children, older adults, people with chronic illnesses, people working or exercising outdoors, and those without proper shelter. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NTstorm@ec.gc.ca or tweet reports using #NTStorm.
Expires: 2024-01-06T14:41:07-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2024-01-05T22:42:16-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.2069163587.2024
Area: Tuktoyaktuk - East Channel Region, Aklavik Region

entry.title: freezing drizzle advisory in effect
entry.summary:
Description: Areas of freezing drizzle are expected or occurring. Hazards: Freezing drizzle producing light ice accretion. Icy and slippery conditions possible, especially on untreated surfaces. Timing: Ending this evening. Discussion: Light snow mixed with freezing drizzle will change to snow this evening. ### Freezing drizzle can produce thin, hard-to-detect layers of ice. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@ec.gc.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.
Expires: 2024-01-06T03:59:24-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2024-01-05T22:27:58-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.1461032010.2024
Area: Red Lake - Woodland Caribou Park, Ear Falls - Perrault Falls - Western Lac Seul, Kenora - Grassy Narrows - Whitedog, Dryden - Vermilion Bay, Ignace - English River, Upsala - Raith, Atikokan - Shebandowan - Quetico Park, Kakabeka Falls - Whitefish Lake - Arrow Lake

entry.title: rainfall warning in effect
entry.summary:
Description: Rain, at times heavy, is expected. When: Now until midnight tonight. Where: Between Qualicum Beach and Fanny Bay. Hazard: 40 to 50 mm of rain. Remarks: A Pacific frontal system will bring rain to Vancouver Island today. Rain will intensify this afternoon with up to 50 mm expected between Qualicum Beach and Fanny Bay by tonight. ### Heavy downpours can cause flash floods and water pooling on roads. Localized flooding in low-lying areas is possible. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to BCstorm@ec.gc.ca or tweet reports using #BCStorm.
Expires: 2024-01-06T09:59:22-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2024-01-05T21:40:35-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.3704184133.2024
Area: East Vancouver Island - Nanoose Bay to Fanny Bay

entry.title: rainfall warning in effect
entry.summary:
Description: Rain, at times heavy, is expected. When: Now until after midnight tonight. Where: Howe Sound. Hazard: 40 to 50 mm of rain. Remarks: A strong onshore flow is developing and will direct a Pacific frontal system towards the south coast. Rain is expected to intensify across the region this afternoon before easing tonight. ### Localized flooding in low-lying areas is possible. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to BCstorm@ec.gc.ca or tweet reports using #BCStorm.
Expires: 2024-01-06T13:36:57-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2024-01-05T21:39:45-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.3615793013.2024
Area: Howe Sound

entry.title: snowfall warning in effect
entry.summary:
Description: Snow, at times heavy, is expected. When: Now until after midnight. Where: Sea to Sky Highway and Whistler. Snowfall accumulation: 15 cm over Whistler, 20 cm over the Sea to Sky Highway. Remarks: An approaching frontal system will bring snow to Whistler and the Sea to Sky Highway. The snow will continue into this evening before easing after midnight. Total snowfall accumulation of 15 to 20 cm are expected by Saturday morning with snow levels hovering near 400 metres for this event. ### Visibility may be suddenly reduced at times in heavy snow. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to BCstorm@ec.gc.ca or tweet reports using #BCStorm.
Expires: 2024-01-06T13:36:36-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2024-01-05T21:38:49-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.3999629182.2024
Area: Whistler

entry.title: freezing drizzle advisory in effect
entry.summary:
Description: Areas of freezing drizzle are expected or occurring. Freezing drizzle continues over southern Manitoba late this afternoon ahead of an area of snow approaching from Saskatchewan. The freezing drizzle is becoming lighter in intensity and will switch over to snow this evening. ### Surfaces such as highways, roads, walkways and parking lots may become icy and slippery. Freezing drizzle advisories are issued when drizzle falling in sub-zero temperatures is expected to freeze on contact, and over time create icy surfaces. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to MBstorm@ec.gc.ca or tweet reports using #MBStorm.
Expires: 2024-01-06T05:00:46-00:00

entry.title: freezing drizzle advisory in effect
entry.summary:
Description: Areas of freezing drizzle are expected or occurring. Hazards: Freezing drizzle producing light ice accretion. Icy and slippery conditions possible, especially on untreated surfaces. Timing: Ending this evening. Discussion: Light snow mixed with freezing drizzle will change to snow this evening. ### Freezing drizzle can produce thin, hard-to-detect layers of ice. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@ec.gc.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.

entry.title: weather advisory in effect
entry.summary:
Description: Winter weather travel advisory in effect for Saturday. Hazards: Total snowfall accumulations of 10 to 20 cm. Reduced visibility in heavy snow. Timing: Beginning early Saturday morning and continuing through Saturday night. Discussion: Snow will begin early Saturday morning and become heavy at times Saturday afternoon. Heavy snow will continue Saturday night and ease by Sunday morning. ### Motorists should expect hazardous winter driving conditions and adjust travel plans accordingly. Surfaces such as highways, roads, walkways and parking lots may become difficult to navigate due to accumulating snow. For road conditions and other traveller information from the Ministry of Transportation, visit https://www.ontario.ca/511, https://www.twitter.com/511Ontario, or call 5-1-1. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@ec.gc.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.

entry.title: weather advisory in effect
entry.summary:
Description: Winter weather travel advisory in effect for tonight through Saturday. Hazards: Total snowfall accumulations of 10 to 20 cm, especially along Highway 17. Reduced visibility in heavy snow. Timing: Beginning this evening and continuing into Saturday afternoon. Discussion: The heaviest snowfall is expected tonight into Saturday morning and will gradually ease Saturday afternoon. Snowfall accumulations are expected to be higher along the shore of Lake Superior, including Highway 17. Light snow will continue Saturday night into Sunday morning. ### Motorists should expect hazardous winter driving conditions and adjust travel plans accordingly. Surfaces such as highways, roads, walkways and parking lots may become difficult to navigate due to accumulating snow. For road conditions and other traveller information from the Ministry of Transportation, visit https://www.ontario.ca/511, https://www.twitter.com/511Ontario, or call 5-1-1. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@ec.gc.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.

entry.title: blizzard warning in effect
entry.summary:
Description: Blizzard conditions with poor visibility in snow and blowing snow are expected or occurring. A low pressure system tracking northward along the coast of Baffin Island is giving strong winds and blizzard conditions to Clyde River. Blizzard conditions will ease overnight or by Saturday morning. ### Travel is expected to be hazardous due to reduced visibility. Visibility will be suddenly reduced to near zero at times in heavy snow and blowing snow. Blizzard warnings are issued when widespread reduced visibilities of 400 metres or less are expected for at least 6 hours. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NUstorm@ec.gc.ca or tweet reports using #NUStorm.
Expires: 2024-01-06T12:08:18-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2024-01-05T20:09:43-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.0812308767.2024
Area: Clyde River

entry.title: special weather statement in effect
entry.summary:
Description: Potential for accumulating snow on Sunday. Locations: southwestern Nova Scotia, including western Halifax County, Lunenburg, Queens, Shelburne, Yarmouth, Digby and southern Annapolis counties. Total snowfall: 5 to 20 cm, with the highest amounts over southern most Yarmouth and Shelburne counties and lesser amounts elsewhere. Maximum wind gusts: Easterly 60 km/h. Time span: From midday Sunday to early Monday morning. Similar storms in the past have caused: - hazardous driving conditions - cancellations of scheduled activities Remarks: Note that this is still an evolving situation, and additional changes in the track of this system could affect forecast snow amounts even further. The system will continue to be closely monitored by ECCC and this statement will be updated with the latest information as required. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NSstorm@ec.gc.ca or tweet reports using #NSStorm.
Expires: 2024-01-06T11:49:02-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2024-01-05T20:00:03-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.2588973193.2024
Area: Annapolis County, Digby County, Lunenburg County, Queens County, Shelburne County, Yarmouth County, Halifax Metro and Halifax County West

entry.title: snow squall watch in effect
entry.summary:
Description: Snow squalls are expected to develop. Under the snow squall bands, visibilities will be significantly reduced due to the heavy snow combined with blowing snow, and snow will quickly accumulate. Total snowfall: locally 10 to 15 cm in snow squalls. Maximum wind gusts: 60 to 70 km/h. Locations: Magdalen Islands. Time span: late this evening until early tomorrow morning. Remarks: Snow squalls in combination with strong winds will lead to reduced visibilities overnight and into early tomorrow morning. ### Snow squalls cause weather conditions to vary considerably; changes from clear skies to heavy snow within just a few kilometres are common. Snow squall watches are issued when conditions are favourable for the formation of bands of snow that could produce intense accumulating snow or near zero visibilities. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NSstorm@ec.gc.ca or tweet reports using #QCStorm.
Expires: 2024-01-06T11:48:35-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2024-01-05T19:56:29-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.1153056488.2024

entry.title: winter storm warning in effect
entry.summary:
Description: Significant snowfall with blowing snow is expected. Further snowfall: 10 to 15 cm. Maximum wind gusts: northwesterly 60 km/h. Time span: ending overnight tonight. Remarks: Snow over the Avalon Peninsula will taper off tonight. Strong northwesterly winds will develop this evening and result in poor visibility at times in blowing snow. ### Visibility may be suddenly reduced at times in heavy snow. Winter storm warnings are issued when multiple types of severe winter weather are expected to occur together. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NLstorm@ec.gc.ca or tweet reports using #NLwx.

entry.title: blizzard warning in effect
entry.summary:
Description: Blizzard conditions with poor visibility in snow and blowing snow are expected or occurring. A low pressure system tracking northward along the coast of Baffin Island is giving strong winds and blizzard conditions to Clyde River this afternoon. The blizzard will continue through tonight before conditions improve on Saturday morning. ### Travel is expected to be hazardous due to reduced visibility. Visibility will be suddenly reduced to near zero at times in heavy snow and blowing snow. Blizzard warnings are issued when widespread reduced visibilities of 400 metres or less are expected for at least 6 hours. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NUstorm@ec.gc.ca or tweet reports using #NUStorm.
Expires: 2024-01-06T10:29:51-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2024-01-05T18:30:57-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.2081541852.2024
Area: Clyde River

entry.title: freezing drizzle advisory in effect
entry.summary:
Description: Areas of freezing drizzle are expected or occurring. An area of freezing drizzle has developed across southern Manitoba this morning ahead of an area of snow approaching from Saskatchewan. The freezing drizzle may be heavy at times this afternoon before switching over to snow this evening. ### Surfaces such as highways, roads, walkways and parking lots may become icy and slippery. Freezing drizzle advisories are issued when drizzle falling in sub-zero temperatures is expected to freeze on contact, and over time create icy surfaces. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to MBstorm@ec.gc.ca or tweet reports using #MBStorm.
Expires: 2024-01-06T02:04:06-00:00

entry.title: freezing drizzle advisory in effect
entry.summary:
Description: Areas of freezing drizzle are expected or occurring. ### Surfaces such as highways, roads, walkways and parking lots may become icy and slippery. Freezing drizzle advisories are issued when drizzle falling in sub-zero temperatures is expected to freeze on contact, and over time create icy surfaces. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to MBstorm@ec.gc.ca or tweet reports using #MBStorm.

entry.title: extreme cold warning in effect
entry.summary:
Description: Extreme cold conditions continue. Hazard: Wind chill values near minus 45. Timing: Continuing into Saturday morning. Discussion: Wind chill values will remain near minus 40 throughout the day. Wind chill values near minus 45 are expected tonight into Saturday morning. ### Extreme cold puts everyone at risk. Risks are greater for young children, older adults, people with chronic illnesses, people working or exercising outdoors, and those without proper shelter. Watch for cold related symptoms: shortness of breath, chest pain, muscle pain and weakness, numbness and colour change in fingers and toes. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@ec.gc.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.

entry.title: extreme cold warning in effect
entry.summary:
Description: A period of very cold wind chills is expected. An Arctic ridge of high pressure will bring a bitterly cold air mass to northern Manitoba on Thursday night into Friday. Temperatures will fall into the mid minus thirties combined with winds of 10 km/h giving extreme wind chills of -45 or colder. Temperatures may moderate slightly over the next few days but extreme cold is likely to return by the end of the weekend into early next week. ### Extreme cold puts everyone at risk. Risks are greater for young children, older adults, people with chronic illnesses, people working or exercising outdoors, and those without proper shelter. Watch for cold related symptoms: shortness of breath, chest pain, muscle pain and weakness, numbness and colour change in fingers and toes. Extreme cold warnings are issued when very cold temperatures or wind chill creates an elevated risk to health such as frost bite and hypothermia. For more information on cold and your health, visit Manitoba Health at https://www.gov.mb.ca/health/publichealth/environmentalhealth/cold.html or call Health Links - Info SantÃ© at 204-788-8200 or toll-free at 1-888-315-9257. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to MBstorm@ec.gc.ca or tweet reports using #MBStorm.
Expires: 2024-01-05T20:09:57-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2024-01-05T15:13:23-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.3465145699.2024
Area: Tadoule Lake

entry.title: special weather statement in effect
entry.summary:
Description: Potential for accumulating snow on Sunday. Locations: southwestern Nova Scotia, including western Halifax County, Lunenburg, Queens, Shelburne, Yarmouth, Digby and southern Annapolis counties. Total snowfall: 5 to 20 cm, with the highest amounts over southern most Yarmouth and Shelburne counties and lesser amounts elsewhere. Maximum wind gusts: Easterly 60 km/h. Time span: From midday Sunday to early Monday morning. Similar storms in the past have caused: - hazardous driving conditions - cancellations of scheduled activities Remarks: Latest indications are that this system will track further offshore than previously expected, hence the heaviest snowfall is now expected to be areas along the South Shore of the province. Note that this is still an evolving situation, and additional changes in the track of this system could affect forecast snow amounts even further. The system will continue to be closely monitored by ECCC and this statement will be updated with the latest information as required. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NSstorm@ec.gc.ca or tweet reports using #NSStorm.
Expires: 2024-01-06T06:50:32-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2024-01-05T14:58:19-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.1371808898.2024
Area: Annapolis County, Digby County, Lunenburg County, Queens County, Shelburne County, Yarmouth County, Halifax Metro and Halifax County West

entry.title: winter storm watch in effect
entry.summary:
Description: Significant snowfall with blowing snow is possible. Total snowfall: 10 to 20 cm. Maximum wind gusts: north to northwesterly near 60 km/h. Locations: the Burin and Bonavista peninsulas, and Clarenville and vicinity. Time span: until tonight. Remarks: A winter storm watch remains in effect due to the possibility of higher snowfall amounts moving into these areas. Should that be the case, moderate winds may also cause significant visibility reduction in blowing snow. The public is advised to monitor future updates throughout this event in case warnings are required. ### Visibility may be suddenly reduced at times in heavy snow. Travel is expected to be hazardous due to reduced visibility in some locations. Winter storm watches are issued when multiple types of severe winter weather are expected to occur together. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NLstorm@ec.gc.ca or tweet reports using #NLwx.
Expires: 2024-01-06T06:28:04-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2024-01-05T14:33:26-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.1424330914.2024
Area: Burin Peninsula, Bonavista Peninsula, Clarenville and vicinity

entry.title: winter storm warning in effect
entry.summary:
Description: Significant snowfall with blowing snow is expected. Total snowfall: 20 to 30 cm. Maximum wind gusts: northerly 60 km/h (strongest near Cape Race). Time span: continuing until overnight tonight. Remarks: Snow over the Avalon Peninsula will increase in intensity this afternoon. Strong northerly winds in conjunction with the fresh snowfall will result in poor visibility in blowing snow tonight. Conditions will improve early Saturday morning, although some local blowing snow may persist on Saturday. ### Visibility may be suddenly reduced at times in heavy snow. Winter storm warnings are issued when multiple types of severe winter weather are expected to occur together. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NLstorm@ec.gc.ca or tweet reports using #NLwx.
Expires: 2024-01-06T06:24:38-00:00

entry.title: extreme cold warning in effect
entry.summary:
Description: A multi-day episode of very cold wind chills is expected. Where: Old Crow community and surrounding areas. When: Now through the weekend. Hazard: Bitterly cold wind chills near minus 50. Remarks: An arctic airmass has settled over the Old Crow area. Temperatures near minus 35 degrees Celsius combined with northeast winds up to 15 km/h can produce wind chill values near minus 50. These extremely cold wind chills will persist until at least Monday. ### Extreme cold puts everyone at risk. Watch for cold related symptoms: shortness of breath, chest pain, muscle pain and weakness, numbness and colour change in fingers and toes. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to YTstorm@ec.gc.ca or tweet reports using #YTStorm.
Expires: 2024-01-06T05:30:41-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2024-01-05T13:33:25-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.2424796134.2024
Area: Old Crow

entry.title: blizzard warning in effect
entry.summary:
Description: Blizzard conditions with gusty winds and persistent visibility near zero in snow and blowing snow are expected or occurring. Where: Dempster highway. When: Now until midday. Hazards: East winds 50 km/h gusting up to 100 km/h, poor visibility in blowing snow, very cold windchill between minus 40 and minus 50, and falling snow accumulating in drifts. Remarks: Between a strong high pressure area over the Arctic and an approaching Pacific frontal system, a strong wind gradient has developed. Winds will gradually diminish over the day. ### Visibility will be suddenly reduced to near zero at times in heavy snow and blowing snow. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to YTstorm@ec.gc.ca or tweet reports using #YTStorm.
Expires: 2024-01-05T22:59:09-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2024-01-05T12:21:32-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.1701681430.2024
Area: Dempster

entry.title: snowfall warning in effect
entry.summary:
Description: Snowfall with total amounts of 15 to 20 cm is expected. Location: North Columbia including Blue River. When: Late this afternoon to Saturday morning Remark: A strong Pacific low pressure system will move across BC today and Saturday. Periods of light snow will start over North Columbia this morning and become heavy this evening. Heavy snow will continue through Saturday morning and ease to periods of light snow Saturday afternoon. ### Rapidly accumulating snow could make travel difficult over some locations. Surfaces such as highways, roads, walkways and parking lots may become difficult to navigate due to accumulating snow. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to BCstorm@ec.gc.ca or tweet reports using #BCStorm.
Expires: 2024-01-06T03:53:04-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2024-01-05T11:58:39-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.0710006253.2024

entry.title: snowfall warning in effect
entry.summary:
Description: Snowfall with total amounts of 15 to 20 cm is expected. Location: Highway 3 - Paulson Summit to Kootenay Pass. When: Early this evening to Saturday afternoon. Remark: A strong Pacific low pressure system will move across BC today and on Saturday. Snow, heavy at times, is expected over Highway 3 from Paulson Summit to Kootenay Pass early this evening through Saturday morning. Snow will taper off Saturday afternoon. ### Rapidly accumulating snow could make travel difficult over some locations. Surfaces such as highways, roads, walkways and parking lots may become difficult to navigate due to accumulating snow. Weather in the mountains can change suddenly resulting in hazardous driving conditions. Road conditions are available at https://www.drivebc.ca/. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to BCstorm@ec.gc.ca or tweet reports using #BCStorm.
Expires: 2024-01-06T03:49:57-00:00

entry.title: extreme cold warning in effect
entry.summary:
Description: A prolonged period of extreme cold conditions begins today. Hazard: Wind chill values near minus 45. Timing: Beginning today and continuing into Saturday morning. Discussion: Extreme cold conditions will begin today as wind chill values drop between minus 40 to 45 through the day. Wind chill values of minus 45 are expected to persist into Saturday morning. ### Extreme cold puts everyone at risk. Risks are greater for young children, older adults, people with chronic illnesses, people working or exercising outdoors, and those without proper shelter. Watch for cold related symptoms: shortness of breath, chest pain, muscle pain and weakness, numbness and colour change in fingers and toes. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@ec.gc.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.
Expires: 2024-01-06T03:49:14-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2024-01-05T11:51:11-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.0927541292.2024
Area: Peawanuck

entry.title: extreme cold warning in effect
entry.summary:
Description: A period of very cold wind chills is expected. An Arctic ridge of high pressure will bring a bitterly cold air mass to northern Manitoba on Thursday night into Friday. Temperatures will fall into the mid minus thirties combined with winds of 10 km/h giving extreme wind chills of -45 or colder. Temperatures may moderate slightly over the next few days but extreme cold is likely to return by the end of the weekend into early next week. ### Extreme cold puts everyone at risk. Risks are greater for young children, older adults, people with chronic illnesses, people working or exercising outdoors, and those without proper shelter. Watch for cold related symptoms: shortness of breath, chest pain, muscle pain and weakness, numbness and colour change in fingers and toes. Extreme cold warnings are issued when very cold temperatures or wind chill creates an elevated risk to health such as frost bite and hypothermia. For more information on cold and your health, visit Manitoba Health at https://www.gov.mb.ca/health/publichealth/environmentalhealth/cold.html or call Health Links - Info SantÃ© at 204-788-8200 or toll-free at 1-888-315-9257. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to MBstorm@ec.gc.ca or tweet reports using #MBStorm.
Expires: 2024-01-05T16:59:28-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2024-01-05T10:48:58-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.3446216648.2024
Area: Tadoule Lake

entry.title: fog advisory in effect
entry.summary:
Description: Near zero visibility in fog is expected or occurring. When: Now until this morning. Locations: North Thompson, North and West Columbia. Remarks: Atmospheric conditions are favourable for the development of dense fog. The fog is expected to dissipate as periods of light snow begins this morning. ### Visibility may be significantly and suddenly reduced to near zero. Travel is expected to be hazardous due to reduced visibility in some locations. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to BCstorm@ec.gc.ca or tweet reports using #BCStorm.
Expires: 2024-01-05T19:14:55-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2024-01-05T10:30:10-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.1317478195.2024
Area: North Thompson, North Columbia, West Columbia

entry.title: special weather statement in effect
entry.summary:
Description: Potential for accumulating snow on Sunday. Locations: southwestern Nova Scotia, including western Halifax County, Lunenburg, Queens, Shelburne, Yarmouth, Digby and southern Annapolis counties. Total snowfall: 5 to 20 cm, with the highest amounts over southern most Yarmouth and Shelburne counties and lesser amounts elsewhere. Maximum wind gusts: Easterly 60 km/h. Time span: From midday Sunday to early Monday morning. Similar storms in the past have caused: - hazardous driving conditions - cancellations of scheduled activities Remarks: Latest indications are that this system will track further offshore than previously expected, hence the heaviest snowfall is now expected to be areas along the South Shore of the province. Note that this is still an evolving situation, and additional changes in the track of this system could affect forecast snow amounts even further. The system will continue to be closely monitored by ECCC and this statement will be updated with the latest information as required. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NSstorm@ec.gc.ca or tweet reports using #NSStorm.
Expires: 2024-01-06T00:34:04-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2024-01-05T08:44:26-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.1179728442.2024
Area: Annapolis County, Digby County, Lunenburg County, Queens County, Shelburne County, Yarmouth County, Halifax Metro and Halifax County West

entry.title: winter storm watch in effect
entry.summary:
Description: Significant snowfall with blowing snow is possible. Total snowfall: 10 to 20 cm. Maximum wind gusts: north to northwesterly near 60 km/h. Locations: the Burin and Bonavista peninsulas, and Clarenville and vicinity. Time span: this morning until tonight. Remarks: A winter storm watch remains in effect due to the possibility of higher snowfall amounts moving into these areas. Should that be the case, moderate winds may also cause significant visibility reduction in blowing snow. The public is advised to monitor future updates throughout this event in case warnings are required. ### Visibility may be suddenly reduced at times in heavy snow. Travel is expected to be hazardous due to reduced visibility in some locations. Winter storm watches are issued when multiple types of severe winter weather are expected to occur together. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NLstorm@ec.gc.ca or tweet reports using #NLwx.
Expires: 2024-01-06T00:15:14-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2024-01-05T08:23:51-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.3264317209.2024
Area: Burin Peninsula, Bonavista Peninsula, Clarenville and vicinity

entry.title: winter storm warning in effect
entry.summary:
Description: Significant snowfall with blowing snow is expected. Total snowfall: Northern Avalon: 20 to 30 cm. Southern Avalon: 25 to 35 cm, with locally higher amounts possible. Maximum wind gusts: northerly 60 to 80 km/h (strongest near Cape Race). Time span: this morning until overnight tonight. Remarks: Snow is expected to begin this morning and become heavy at times by the afternoon. Strong northerly winds and falling temperatures in conjunction with the fresh snowfall will result in poor visibility in blowing snow, especially tonight. Conditions will improve early Saturday morning, although some local blowing snow will persists on Saturday due to strengthening winds. ### Visibility may be suddenly reduced at times in heavy snow. Winter storm warnings are issued when multiple types of severe winter weather are expected to occur together. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NLstorm@ec.gc.ca or tweet reports using #NLwx.
Expires: 2024-01-06T00:16:40-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2024-01-05T08:20:45-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.2339500365.2024
Area: Avalon Peninsula North, Avalon Peninsula Southeast, St. John's and vicinity, Avalon Peninsula Southwest

entry.title: rainfall warning in effect
entry.summary:
Description: Rain, at times heavy, is expected. When: This morning until midnight tonight. Where: Between Qualicum Beach and Fanny Bay. Hazard: 40 to 50 mm of rain. Remarks: A Pacific frontal system will bring rain to Vancouver Island today. Rain will intensify this afternoon with up to 50 mm expected between Qualicum Beach and Fanny Bay by tonight. ### Heavy downpours can cause flash floods and water pooling on roads. Localized flooding in low-lying areas is possible. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to BCstorm@ec.gc.ca or tweet reports using #BCStorm.
Expires: 2024-01-06T00:06:11-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2024-01-05T08:16:57-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.2187673878.2024
Area: East Vancouver Island - Nanoose Bay to Fanny Bay

entry.summary:

entry.title: snowfall warning in effect
entry.summary:
Description: Snow, at times heavy, is expected. When: Beginning near noon until after midnight. Where: Sea to Sky Highway and Whistler. Snowfall accumulation: 15 cm over Whistler, 20 cm over the Sea to Sky Highway. Remarks: An approaching frontal system will bring snow to Whistler and the Sea to Sky Highway. The snow will begin near noon and continue into this evening before easing after midnight. Snowfall amounts of 15 to 20 cm are expected by Saturday morning with snow levels hovering near 400 metres for this event. ### Visibility may be suddenly reduced at times in heavy snow. Weather in the mountains can change suddenly resulting in hazardous driving conditions. Road conditions are available at https://www.drivebc.ca/. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to BCstorm@ec.gc.ca or tweet reports using #BCStorm.
Expires: 2024-01-06T00:04:25-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2024-01-05T08:11:09-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.4277542696.2024
Area: Sea to Sky - Squamish to Whistler

entry.title: extreme cold warning in effect
entry.summary:
Description: A prolonged period of extreme cold conditions begins today. Hazard: Wind chill values near minus 45. Timing: Beginning today and continuing into Saturday morning. Discussion: Extreme cold conditions will begin today as wind chill values drop between minus 40 to 45 through the day. Wind chill values of minus 45 are expected to persist into Saturday morning. ### Extreme cold puts everyone at risk. Risks are greater for young children, older adults, people with chronic illnesses, people working or exercising outdoors, and those without proper shelter. Watch for cold related symptoms: shortness of breath, chest pain, muscle pain and weakness, numbness and colour change in fingers and toes. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@ec.gc.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.
Expires: 2024-01-05T21:54:38-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2024-01-05T05:58:38-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.3549540925.2024
Area: Peawanuck

entry.title: extreme cold warning in effect
entry.summary:
Description: A multi-day episode of extreme cold conditions. Hazard: Wind chill values near minus 45. Timing: Today continuing into Saturday morning. Discussion: Extreme cold conditions will begin this morning as wind chill values drop to near minus 45. Not much relief is expected this afternoon as wind chill values will remain near minus 40 through the day. Extreme cold conditions are expected to persist into Saturday morning. ### Extreme cold puts everyone at risk. Risks are greater for young children, older adults, people with chronic illnesses, people working or exercising outdoors, and those without proper shelter. Watch for cold related symptoms: shortness of breath, chest pain, muscle pain and weakness, numbness and colour change in fingers and toes. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@ec.gc.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.

entry.title: weather advisory in effect
entry.summary:
Description: Winter weather travel advisory in effect. Hazards: Locally heavy snowfall with total accumulations of 5 to 10 cm. Reduced visibility at times in heavy snow. Timing: Tonight into Friday morning. Discussion: Lake effect snow developing over Georgian Bay is affecting the area. The snow is expected to taper off Friday morning. ### Motorists should expect hazardous winter driving conditions and adjust travel plans accordingly. Travel may be hazardous due to sudden changes in the weather. Surfaces such as highways, roads, walkways and parking lots may become difficult to navigate due to accumulating snow. For road conditions and other traveller information from the Ministry of Transportation, visit https://www.ontario.ca/511, https://www.twitter.com/511Ontario, or call 5-1-1. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@ec.gc.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.
Expires: 2024-01-05T16:03:39-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2024-01-05T03:33:57-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.3739771872.2024
Area: Town of Parry Sound - Rosseau - Killbear Park, Port Carling - Port Severn

entry.title: freezing drizzle advisory in effect
entry.summary:
Description: Areas of freezing drizzle are expected or occurring. Location: northern Avalon Peninsula. Time span: ending overnight tonight. Remarks: Significant ice accretion is possible, especially over highest elevations. ### Surfaces such as highways, roads, walkways and parking lots may become icy and slippery. Freezing drizzle advisories are issued when drizzle falling in sub-zero temperatures is expected to freeze on contact, and over time create icy surfaces. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NLstorm@ec.gc.ca or tweet reports using #NLwx.
Expires: 2024-01-05T09:59:34-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2024-01-05T02:04:46-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.0996986330.2024
Area: Avalon Peninsula North, St. John's and vicinity

entry.title: winter storm watch in effect
entry.summary:
Description: Significant snowfall with blowing snow is possible. Total snowfall: 10 to 15 cm. Maximum wind gusts: north to northwesterly near 60 km/h. Locations: the Burin and Bonavista peninsulas, and Clarenville and vicinity. Time span: Friday morning until Friday night. Remarks: A winter storm watch remains in effect due to the possibility of higher snowfall amounts moving into these areas. Should that be the case, moderate winds may also cause significant visibility reduction in blowing snow. The public is advised to monitor future updates throughout this event in case warnings are required. ### Visibility may be suddenly reduced at times in heavy snow. Travel is expected to be hazardous due to reduced visibility in some locations. Winter storm watches are issued when multiple types of severe winter weather are expected to occur together. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NLstorm@ec.gc.ca or tweet reports using #NLwx.
Expires: 2024-01-05T18:02:37-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2024-01-05T02:04:18-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.0824559350.2024
Area: Burin Peninsula, Bonavista Peninsula, Clarenville and vicinity

entry.title: winter storm warning in effect
entry.summary:
Description: Significant snowfall with blowing snow is expected. Total snowfall: Northern Avalon: 20 to 30 cm. Southern Avalon: 25 to 35 cm, with locally higher amounts possible. Maximum wind gusts: northerly 60 to 80 km/h (strongest near Cape Race). Time span: Friday morning until overnight Friday night. Remarks: Snow is expected to begin Friday morning and become heavy at times by Friday afternoon. Strong northerly winds and falling temperatures in conjunction with the fresh snowfall will result in poor visibility in blowing snow, especially Friday night. Conditions will improve early Saturday morning, although some local blowing snow may continue on Saturday due to strengthening winds. ### Visibility may be suddenly reduced at times in heavy snow. Winter storm warnings are issued when multiple types of severe winter weather are expected to occur together. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NLstorm@ec.gc.ca or tweet reports using #NLwx.
Expires: 2024-01-05T18:01:48-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2024-01-05T02:03:18-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.1475173153.2024
Area: Avalon Peninsula North, Avalon Peninsula Southeast, St. John's and vicinity, Avalon Peninsula Southwest

entry.title: special weather statement in effect
entry.summary:
Description: Potential for significant snow on Sunday. Locations: Mainland Nova Scotia, though highest snowfall amounts most likely along the South Shore. Total snowfall: 5 to 10 cm for northern and eastern mainland, 15 to 25 cm for parts of the South Shore. Maximum wind gusts: Easterly 40 to 60 km/h, potentially higher gusts along the Atlantic coast Time span: From Sunday afternoon into Monday. Similar storms in the past have caused: - hazardous driving conditions - school closures or delayed openings - cancellations of scheduled activities Remarks: Note that this is an evolving situation several days away, and there are some recent indications that this system could track further offshore than previously expected, meaning snowfall amounts could be less than previously expected above for many areas. The system will continue to be closely monitored by ECCC and this statement will be updated with the latest information as required. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NSstorm@ec.gc.ca or tweet reports using #NSStorm.
Expires: 2024-01-05T17:44:01-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2024-01-05T01:58:48-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.0431969766.2024
Area: Kings County, Annapolis County, Digby County, Lunenburg County, Queens County, Shelburne County, Yarmouth County, Cumberland County - Minas Shore, Cumberland County North and Cobequid Pass, Colchester County - Cobequid Bay, Colchester County North, Hants County, Colchester County - Truro and south, Halifax Metro and Halifax County West, Halifax County - east of Porters Lake, Pictou County, Guysborough County, Antigonish County

entry.title: extreme cold warning in effect
entry.summary:
Description: A prolonged period of very cold wind chills is expected. Where: Old Crow community and surrounding areas. When: Now through Friday. Hazard: Bitterly cold wind chills near minus 50. Remarks: An arctic airmass will settle over the Old Crow area. Daytime and overnight temperatures will be between minus 35 and minus 40. The cold temperatures combined with wind up to 15 km/h will produce wind chills near minus 50 at times. These extremely cold wind chills will persist until late Friday or early Saturday when warmer air and clouds are expected. ### Extreme cold puts everyone at risk. Risks are greater for young children, older adults, people with chronic illnesses, people working or exercising outdoors, and those without proper shelter. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to YTstorm@ec.gc.ca or tweet reports using #YTStorm.
Expires: 2024-01-05T17:45:43-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2024-01-05T01:54:19-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.3767002197.2024
Area: Old Crow

entry.title: blizzard warning in effect
entry.summary:
Description: Blizzard conditions with gusty winds and persistent visibility near zero in snow and blowing snow are expected or occurring. Where: Dempster highway. When: Now through midday Friday. Hazards: East winds 50 km/h gusting up to 100 km/h, poor visibility in blowing snow, very cold windchill between minus 40 and minus 50, and falling snow accumulating in drifts. Remarks: Between a strong high pressure area over the Arctic and an approaching Pacific frontal system, a strong wind gradient has developed. Winds will be strongest this evening before gradually diminishing. ### Visibility will be suddenly reduced to near zero at times in heavy snow and blowing snow. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to YTstorm@ec.gc.ca or tweet reports using #YTStorm.
Expires: 2024-01-05T17:45:29-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2024-01-05T01:48:21-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.2144655871.2024
Area: Dempster

entry.title: fog advisory in effect
entry.summary:
Description: Near zero visibility in fog is expected or occurring. Dense fog continues over southwestern Saskatchewan this evening with visibilities worsening as the sun sets. This fog advisory may be expanded as the evening progresses. Improvement is expected by Friday morning. ### Visibility may be significantly and suddenly reduced to near zero. Travel is expected to be hazardous due to reduced visibility in some locations. Fog advisories are issued when near zero visibilities in fog are expected or occurring. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to SKstorm@ec.gc.ca or tweet reports using #SKStorm.
Expires: 2024-01-05T15:36:03-00:00

entry.title: fog advisory in effect
entry.summary:
Description: Near zero visibility in fog is occurring. Dense fog is expected to persist until Friday morning. ### Travel is expected to be hazardous due to reduced visibility in some locations. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ABstorm@ec.gc.ca or tweet reports using #ABStorm.

entry.title: fog advisory in effect
entry.summary:
Description: Near zero visibility in fog is expected or occurring. ### Visibility may be significantly and suddenly reduced to near zero. Travel is expected to be hazardous due to reduced visibility in some locations. Fog advisories are issued when near zero visibilities in fog are expected or occurring. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to SKstorm@ec.gc.ca or tweet reports using #SKStorm.
Expires: 2024-01-05T15:36:03-00:00

entry.title: extreme cold warning in effect
entry.summary:
Description: Extremely cold wind chill values are expected or occurring. Wind chill values between -50 to -55 are expected overnight. Some regions will see these extreme cold values persist through the weekend. ### Extreme cold puts everyone at risk. Risks are greater for young children, older adults, people with chronic illnesses, people working or exercising outdoors, and those without proper shelter. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NTstorm@ec.gc.ca or tweet reports using #NTStorm.
Expires: 2024-01-05T14:26:21-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2024-01-04T22:27:57-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.2775033110.2024
Area: Colville Lake, North Slave Region including Wekweeti - Whati - Behchoko

entry.title: extreme cold warning in effect
entry.summary:
Description: A period of very cold wind chills is expected. An Arctic ridge of high pressure will bring a bitterly cold air mass to northern Manitoba on Thursday night into Friday. Temperatures will fall into the mid minus thirties combined with winds of 10 km/h giving extreme wind chills of -45 or colder. Temperatures may moderate slightly over the next few days but extreme cold is likely to return by the end of the weekend into early next week. ### Extreme cold puts everyone at risk. Risks are greater for young children, older adults, people with chronic illnesses, people working or exercising outdoors, and those without proper shelter. Watch for cold related symptoms: shortness of breath, chest pain, muscle pain and weakness, numbness and colour change in fingers and toes. Extreme cold warnings are issued when very cold temperatures or wind chill creates an elevated risk to health such as frost bite and hypothermia. For more information on cold and your health, visit Manitoba Health at https://www.gov.mb.ca/health/publichealth/environmentalhealth/cold.html or call Health Links - Info SantÃ© at 204-788-8200 or toll-free at 1-888-315-9257. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to MBstorm@ec.gc.ca or tweet reports using #MBStorm.
Expires: 2024-01-05T13:19:47-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2024-01-04T21:29:24-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.1584931852.2024
Area: Tadoule Lake

entry.title: extreme cold warning in effect
entry.summary:
Description: A prolonged period of extreme cold conditions begins Friday morning. Hazard: Wind chill values near minus 45. Timing: Beginning Friday morning and continuing into Saturday morning. Discussion: Extreme cold conditions will begin Friday morning as wind chill values drop to near minus 45. Conditions are expected to be even colder Friday night, with wind chill values between minus 45 and minus 50. ### Extreme cold puts everyone at risk. Risks are greater for young children, older adults, people with chronic illnesses, people working or exercising outdoors, and those without proper shelter. Watch for cold related symptoms: shortness of breath, chest pain, muscle pain and weakness, numbness and colour change in fingers and toes. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@ec.gc.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.

entry.title: winter storm watch in effect
entry.summary:
Description: Significant snowfall with blowing snow is possible. Total snowfall: 10 to 15 cm. Maximum wind gusts: north to northwesterly near 60 km/h. Locations: the Burin and Bonavista peninsulas, and Clarenville and vicinity. Time span: Friday morning until Friday night. Remarks: A winter storm watch remains in effect due to the possibility of higher snowfall amounts moving into these areas. Should that be the case, moderate winds may also cause significant visibility reduction in blowing snow. The public is advised to monitor future updates throughout this event in case warnings are required. ### Visibility may be suddenly reduced at times in heavy snow. Travel is expected to be hazardous due to reduced visibility in some locations. Winter storm watches are issued when multiple types of severe winter weather are expected to occur together. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NLstorm@ec.gc.ca or tweet reports using #NLwx.
Expires: 2024-01-05T11:31:40-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2024-01-04T19:37:54-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.1732344675.2024

entry.title: freezing drizzle advisory in effect
entry.summary:
Description: Areas of freezing drizzle are expected or occurring. Location: northern Avalon Peninsula. Time span: ending overnight tonight. Remarks: Significant ice accretion is possible, especially over highest elevations. ### Surfaces such as highways, roads, walkways and parking lots may become icy and slippery. Freezing drizzle advisories are issued when drizzle falling in sub-zero temperatures is expected to freeze on contact, and over time create icy surfaces. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NLstorm@ec.gc.ca or tweet reports using #NLwx.

entry.title: winter storm warning in effect
entry.summary:
Description: Significant snowfall with blowing snow is expected. Total snowfall: Northern Avalon: 20 to 30 cm. Southern Avalon: 25 to 35 cm, with locally higher amounts possible. Maximum wind gusts: northerly 60 to 80 km/h (strongest near Cape Race). Time span: Friday morning until overnight Friday night. Remarks: Snow is expected to begin Friday morning and become heavy at times by Friday afternoon. Strong northerly winds and falling temperatures in conjunction with the fresh snowfall will result in poor visibility in blowing snow, especially Friday night. Conditions will improve early Saturday morning, although some local blowing snow may continue on Saturday due to strengthening winds. ### Visibility may be suddenly reduced at times in heavy snow. Winter storm warnings are issued when multiple types of severe winter weather are expected to occur together. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NLstorm@ec.gc.ca or tweet reports using #NLwx.
Expires: 2024-01-05T11:19:56-00:00
